text: RT @CDCgov: CDC has shortened the recommended time for #COVID19 isolation and quarantine. Learn more about what to do if you test positive‚Ä¶

Nice to start the day on one of my favorite shows, @NPR's @MorningEdition, with @FoodieScience (Michaeleen Doucleff) talking Covid case numbers/hospitalizations and what we're seeing here in San Francisco. https://t.co/zoaWEemE39

RT @Craig_A_Spencer: I‚Äôve seen a lot of Covid in the ER recently.

With so many people getting infected recently, some folks may wonder wha‚Ä¶
RT @ScottGottliebMD: Age-adjusted rates of Covid associated hospitalizations by vaccine status. Adults over age 18. Data from Jan-Nov 2021‚Ä¶

And 1 more: w/ more + tests in pts w/ mild disease, a new data interpretation issue rears its head: More hospital pts who HAVE Covid (+ test) but aren't here FOR Covid. Yet they'll prob. be counted in Covid hospital #'s. Another thing that may make severity look worse than it is.

In looking at new Omicron severity info, keep in mind:
1) Lots of cases now dxed via home tests. Since +'s won't show up in case counts,‚¨áin severity may be even greater. 
2) Much of ‚¨áin severity is from immunity. Likely‚Äìbut can't prove‚Äìthat Omi's milder w/ no vax or past Covid.

RT @AliNouriPhD: üìåCOVID19 can transmit between people even without each other‚Äôs physical presence‚Äîin poorly ventilated areas.

Case study:‚Ä¶

A few of my more astute readers have pointed out (thanks!) I got the math wrong (sorry): if crowd is 25 people & the probability of each having Covid is 4.6%, then the probability of someone having Covid is 69%, not a near certainty. Don't reach >90% chance until ~45 in crowd.

The disconnect between cases/test pos. and hospitalizations/severe illnesses now seems very solid, & it‚Äôs the best Covid news we‚Äôve gotten for months. Don‚Äôt let your guard down (I‚Äôm not). But it‚Äôs possible we‚Äôll get thru winter without being nearly as crushed as I feared.(25/end)

Now that I‚Äôve scared the pants off you, let‚Äôs turn to hospitalizations @UCSFHospitals. Like SF generally, it's also quite reassuring: our hospital #'s remain very low. We currently have 10 Covid patients in our hospital, as low as we‚Äôve been for the past few months (Fig).(18/25) https://t.co/hJP3jTmXjk

‚Ä¶ they had Covid, but, last week, only ~1 in 30 actually did. 
Well, that # has also skyrocketed, now a 7-d avg of 17.5% (this also this underestimates the true risk: recent days have been closer to 25%, or 1 in 4.) I don‚Äôt recall it ever being that high here before.(17/25)

You may have noticed the other (upper) curve on the chart (Fig shown again). Ten days ago, our SYMPTOMATIC test + rate was 3.5%. These are tests of people who sought medical attention because they had symptoms consistent with Covid. Of course, all of them were "sure"‚Ä¶(16/25) https://t.co/2HYt9uFwcN

This means that, if you find yourself in a closed space in SF with 25 other people who feel fine, it‚Äôs a near certainty that one of them has Covid. And since it‚Äôs likely they have Omicron, their virus is about twice as transmissible as it would have been last month.(13/25)

And now (drumroll), over the last few days that number has been ~4.6%! (Figure; the 7-day avg, seen on the chart [2.98%], is lagging since the rate is climbing so steeply.) This implies that the chance of an asymptomatic person in SF having Covid is now nearly 1 in 20.(12/25) https://t.co/W4iRwC9zpR

For reference, the lowest our asymptomatic test pos. rate @UCSFHospitals ever got (pre-Delta) was ~0.2%, or ~1 in 500 patients. The rate was 0.92% on Dec 14, 10 days ago. So on that day, about one in 110 patients with no symptoms of Covid tested positive. (11/25)

‚Ä¶ the chances that a person near you actually has Covid and is infectious. As prevalence in a community goes up, the chances of you getting Covid from an encounter goes right up with it, even if nothing else has changed. So prevalence is pretty key in thinking about risk.(9/25)

Remember that your chances of catching Covid in a given setting (restaurant, flight, etc) if a function of the characteristics of the virus (Omicron being more infectious) x protection (particularly vax status and masks) x setting (indoor, ventilation, etc) x (CRUCIALLY)‚Ä¶(8/25)

‚Ä¶ is admitted or has an outpatient procedure ‚Äì everything from cancer surgery to a heart attack to a colonoscopy ‚Äì is tested for Covid. I use this number to estimate the chance that somebody sitting at a nearby table in a San Francisco restaurant has asymptomatic Covid.(7/25)

For a closer look, let‚Äôs dive into data from @UCSFHospitals. As you may recall, one of my go-to numbers is our ‚Äúasymptomatic test positivity rate.‚Äù This is the rate of positive Covid tests in patients have no Covid symptoms ‚Äì we have this useful number since every pt who‚Ä¶(6/25)

Covid (@UCSF) Chronicles, Day 647 (!)
I haven‚Äôt done a San Francisco update for a while. Now seems like a good time, since SF¬†‚Äì the most vaxxed big city in the U.S. ‚Äì¬†may offer lessons for the nation about how an Omicron surge is influenced by high vax (& masking) rates.(1/25)

Anybody who says "I hate Twitter" has never tried to keep up with a pandemic in which crucial new data is released every few hours, data that often requires sophisticated interpretation by domain experts in areas ranging from virology to epidemiology to supply chain to sociology.

The bad news: virtually every piece of good news in the two years of this damn pandemic has been followed by bad news.
(25/end)

More bad news: After 2 yrs, we don‚Äôt understand much about Long Covid, & don‚Äôt know its prevalence w/ Omicron, after vax, etc. It remains a hardship for millions, and a lingering concern for me as I think about the prospect of getting even a ‚Äúmild‚Äù case of Omicron.(22/25)

‚Ä¶and then you‚Äôll need access to the drug. Pfizer anticipates having 180K doses by January 1 ‚Äì there were 190,000 Americans dxed w/ Covid YESTERDAY! So as Covid cases soar, we'll see real bottlenecks in access to the meds (MAbs & Paxlovid mostly) that can truly lower risk.(13/25)
